MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP620201323
Licensee Group Organization: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Designee: Demetrius LuJuan Starling
Chief Administrator: Lindsey Lassanske
Agency Name: NEWAYGO/LAKE COUNTY DHHS
Agency Address: 1018 E NEWELL ST
WHITE CLOUD, MI 49349-8795
License Status: Regular
License Expiration Date: 09/25/2024
II. METHODOLOGY

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12306 Application request
Section
Description
1

(1) An agency shall provide an orientation for prospective
applicants for a foster home license before a foster home
application is provided.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The agency did not provide an opportunity for a prospective foster
parent to complete an orientation.
Investigation Licensing Supervisor (LS) was interviewed via telephone on
October 19, 2023. He stated he first spoke with the Complainant
in March 2023. Complainant had contacted Newaygo/Lake DHHS
and had some general questions regarding fostering and
adoption. LS stated he had a lengthy conversation with the
Complainant and answered his questions about the process. LS
stated the questions were broad and general. Complainant had
indicated to LS that he was blind and inquired whether or not
someone who is blind would be able to foster or adopt. LS stated
he told Complainant that being blind or having a disability does not
prohibit someone from being a foster parent or adoptive parent.
LS stated there was some discussion around that and he
answered all of Complainant’s questions. LS stated he discussed
some of the basic steps that are involved in licensing related to
the questions he had; specifically, those relating to an applicant
with a disability. LS stated he explained the medical statements
that are submitted for applicants. He discussed the preference of
the applicant related to child characteristics and how that is
assessed. Complainant reported to LS that he was only interested
in infant males that were not circumcised and medically fragile. LS
stated he discussed that due to the specificity of his preference he
was not sure how many children would meet those criteria.
Complainant reported to LS that he was primarily interested in
adopting a child. Complainant also reported to LS that he resides
with his parents and his parents were not interested in fostering
and were adamantly opposed to Complainant being a foster
parent. LS stated there was some discussion regarding all
household members are assessed and explained the reason
behind that. Complainant identified that as a barrier and stated he
would have a conversation with his parents regarding his desire to
foster or adopt and then would follow up with the agency if he
wished to pursue further. LS stated he asked Complainant if he
was interested in agencies that focus on adoption and he stated
he was interested but did not want the information mailed to his
home. He reported to LS that he has software on his computer
that will read information that is in the body of the email, so LS
agreed to email some information to him. LS stated he asked
Licensing Worker 2 to email Complainant with some general
information as well as some information about adoption agencies.
2

LS stated Complainant did not respond to the email or call the
agency back.
LS stated he received an email from an outside agency in July
indicating the Complainant had contacted them and said he had
made attempts to contact Newaygo/Lake DHHS but was not
receiving a response. The email also stated Complainant might be
interested in orientation and an application. LS followed up with
the other agency and indicated they had not heard from the
Complainant, but they would follow up with him. LS stated he
asked Licensing Worker 1 to contact Complainant who was able
to connect with him. LS stated Licensing Worker 1 informed him
she spoke with Complainant and was able to answer his
questions. Complainant indicated his situation had not changed as
far as his living situation and his parents were still opposed to him
fostering. Complainant also reported the agency could not mail
anything to the house and no one could come out to his house to
meet with him or his family. LS stated when he followed up with
Licensing Worker 1 regarding her conversation with Complainant,
Complainant’s focus was on his frustration with lack of housing
options.
LS stated during his communication with Complainant, he
answered all of his questions and Complainant did not ask for
orientation or options for orientation. LS stated to his knowledge
Complainant had not asked Licensing Worker 1 about orientation
or accommodations for him to be able to complete orientation over
the telephone.
LS stated when individuals contact their agency regarding the
fostering process it typically starts with answering general
questions and if the individual is interested in moving forward, the
agency will connect them to a licensing worker in order to
complete orientation. Regarding the Complainant, LS stated he
answered his questions and Complainant was going to follow up
with his parents and let the agency know if he wanted to move
forward. LS stated there was no conversation with the
Complainant regarding the orientation process because it never
got that far. He stated the Complainant did not indicate he wanted
to complete orientation and did not identify any barriers for the
orientation process. LS stated the agency would have done all
they could to accommodate him.
Licensing Worker 1 (LW1) was interviewed via telephone on
October 19, 2023. She stated her first interaction with the
Complainant was approximately 2017 or 2018. He had contacted
3

the agency and indicated he was interested in fostering an
uncircumcised male infant. He had indicated that he was blind and
unable to drive and there was discussion regarding his questions.
More recently, LW1 had a conversation with Complainant who
indicated he is still living with his parents, and they continue to not
support his efforts to foster or adopt and would not cooperate with
the licensing process. LW1 explained the first step would be an
orientation and she would come out to his house. She stated she
was told by Complainant she was not allowed to send anything to
his home or come out to his home. LW1 stated she explained to
Complainant his parents would need to be on the license because
they are in the home. She stated he indicated he was going to
discuss with his parents and let her know but stated he might just
continue to work with another agency he had communicated with.
LW1 believes he meant the foster care navigator that was
assisting him. LW1 stated Complainant then asked multiple
questions regarding lack of rental options that are available to him
and felt he was being discriminated against regarding housing.
LW1 stated Complainant did not request orientation. He had
asked questions and the process was discussed but he never
asked for orientation or the options available for him to complete
orientation. The primary focus of the conversation was regarding
housing and Complainant’s feeling that he was being
discriminated against regarding housing options. LW1 stated the
agency will typically conduct orientations at the home of the
prospective foster parents but has also offered orientation in the
agency office.
Licensing Worker 2 (LW2) was interviewed via telephone on
October 19, 2023. She stated LS had a conversation with
Complainant and asked her to follow up with an email that
provided information he had requested. She stated she sent an
email to Complainant in March 2023 but did not receive a
response.
Complainant was interviewed via telephone on October 19,
2023. He stated he initially contacted the agency late summer and
spoke with LS and asked specific questions regarding the required
paperwork and his disability. He stated LS told him the agency
would not be able to assist him. Complainant stated he was
interested in fostering a medically fragile newborn male. His
ultimate goal would be to adopt. He stated LS told him that due to
his vision and other medical issues he would not be able to foster.
He stated the agency wanted to send documents to him via US
mail, but he requested email so that he could utilize his document
reading software and was told they could not email him
4

information. He stated the agency never sent him anything via
email and only sent information via snail mail.
Complainant stated he asked LS if there was an option to
complete orientation via telephone due to transportation barriers.
He stated he is able to set up transportation, but it can be
challenging and inquired if he could complete orientation over the
telephone. He stated LS stated orientation via the telephone was
not an option and he would need to report to the agency in order
to complete orientation. He stated he attempted to inquire if
orientation could then be completed at his house and was again
told that he needed to report to the agency for orientation. He
stated on the ADA website there is information that certain training
needs to be modified to accommodate a disability. He stated he
explained to LS that he is not able to physically report to the
agency.
He stated he did not have communication with anyone other than
LS and a woman whom he could not recall her name or what
agency she was employed. He could not recall any
communication with LS other than in July.
He stated he would like to foster and wants to proceed with
orientation but would need an agency that can accommodate his
disability. He would be willing to move forward with Newaygo/Lake
DHHS if they are willing to work with him. He stated he preferred
to be the only individual assessed due to his parents being against
him fostering but he would do what is necessary and required. He
stated he never informed the agency he needed to follow up with
his parents.
During the investigation Complainant indicated he would like to
move forward with the orientation process. A follow up
conversation with the Chief Administrator and Licensing
Supervisor occurred on October 27, 2023. They were advised
Complainant would like to complete orientation. The agency
indicated they would contact him regarding the next steps. LS had
previously indicated during his interview that he would do what he
could to accommodate the Complainant.
Documents reviewed:
• Email from LW2 to Complainant dated March 28, 2023.
Email explained some components of the licensing process
including assessing all household members, obtaining
medical clearances and provided Complainant with contact
5

information regarding adoption agencies that service his
area.
• Email from Complainant to LS dated November 7, 2023.
Complainant confirms receipt of earlier email from LS and
asks if his orientation can wait until after the holidays.
Response sent from LS to Complainant on November 7,
2023, states it is fine to schedule orientation after the
holidays. LS asks Complainant to send an email or call him
when he is ready to schedule orientation.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance. Based on completed
interviews there is no evidence to support the allegation the
agency did not offer foster parent orientation to Complainant. The
correspondence that took place between the agency and
Complainant included answering general questions and providing
an overview of the licensing process.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
It is recommended no change to the license status of this child placing agency.
______November 14, 2023
Melinda Gubbins Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
November 14, 2023
